captions.text: Redheads aren't going extinct.

They aren't soulless-- well,
any more than anyone else is,

scientifically
speaking-- and they've
been around for a long time.
[MUSIC PLAYING]
Hey, gingers and others!

Trace here from DNews to
settle some old scores

about those redheaded
people among us.

Now before I dive
in, you can probably
tell I am not a redhead.

Although when I let
my beard grow out,

I do get little red hairs, so
I don't know what that means.

Anyway, redheads
get a lot of flack,

so we explored some of the
science behind their freckles.

Redheads have been in
literature for a while.

The Oxford English Dictionary
says the term "redhead" first

appeared in 1510
and it's associated

with a fair complexion and
Auburn or ginger colored hair.

But the gene mutation
that causes redheadedness
has been around much longer.

It came about 50,000 years ago
when humans moved from Africa

into the cloudier
climbs of Europe.

The redheaded human is a
result of a gene mutation

on the MC1R gene, which is
responsible for controlling

melanin production,
probably not a surprise.

Melanin is what gives skin,
eyes, and hair their color.

Blonds are also a result of
the change in the MC1R gene.

New research published
in the journal

Molecular Biology and Evolution
discovered another mutation

that causes fairer
skin complexion.

Scientists discovered
it while analyzing

the DNA of 1,000
people from Spain

and figure it's
our body's response

to lower vitamin D production
from the lessened sun
outside of Africa.

Sadly, the mutation
goes hand in hand

with lessened protection
from UV rays as well.

Darker skin reflect the rays
better than lighter, so fair

skin has a higher risk for
melanoma, or skin cancer.

When lab rats with comparable
pigmentation were tested,

50% developed melanoma
before they were even
exposed to the UV light!

So get out there and
get tested redheads.

So while some of those sayings
about redheads are true,
rumors of redhead extinction?
Grossly exaggerated.

In 2005, the internet was abuzz
with a source at the Oxford

Hair Foundation claiming
the recessive gene was
disappearing.

In reality 80% of humanity
carry the recessive gene

underneath their
own dominate one.

It's important to note that
the gene is double recessive.

So both parents must
carry it to birth
their own little gingersnap.

And in total, 2% to 6% of humans
in the Northern Hemisphere

and only 1% to 2%
worldwide are gingers.

This rare gene mutation
has been rumored

to affect other
redhead traits as well.
For example, pain reception.

Even the MythBusters
explored this phenomenon.

Anesthesiologists
know that redheads

do need more of the
lidocaine anesthetic

before surgery, about 20%
more than dark haired people,
in fact.

However, when it comes
to opiate painkillers,
they actually need less.

This has to do with pain
receptors being triggered

differently in people
with MCR1 mutations.

Did you have misconceptions
about redheads before?
Be honest, everybody.

Share your thoughts with
us on our Facebook page.

And thanks for
watching DNews today.

We air twice daily,
seven days a week.

So if you like
what you're seeing,

save testtube.com/dnews as a
favorite so you don't miss any.
It's easy.
Thanks again.
{MUSIC PLAYING]

comments.text:
My first husband had dark brown hair and I had blond hair. We were checking 
out at the grocery store one day and I was holding our red haired baby, 
when an elderly woman came up to me and asked, "Where'd he get his red 
hair?" in a harsh, accusatory tone. I liked her up and down and sternly 
said, "FROM GOD"! she promptly walked away. My husband's father in law had 
red hair. I have a brother with red hair and my dad's family is peppered 
with rare red hair. Non red heads can be blessed with red heads!﻿

i had to have 10 shots in my jaw to remove one wisdom tooth. As far as

physical impacts i tolerate higher levels. Most redheads are very 
passionate pple, hince the short temper and passionate high intensity love 
making. I notice i can smell scents faster than other ppl, i sense 
temperature/climate change, I can usually tell its going to rain later that 
day or next day because I will get a headache before hand. I do notice that 
i put off a body odor smell, sweet musk kindof smell. I try not to get to 
much sun as i burn after an hour. What red heads lack in skin color, they 
makeup in other hidden areas if you know what i mean. So if u a red head, 
take care of yourself, get urself healthy, and love urself. Haters will

comments.text:
OK, that pain thing is weird. Interesting but weird. My hair has gone 
through a gambit of changes from the time I was born. It's changed color on 
its own, and I've changed it a couple of times. My dad was the same way. He 
was a redhead until his 30s, then a brunette. My cousins on his side were 
all born redheads but one...and now only one still has red hair...

But back to the pain thing. First...I have a very high tolerance to pain. 
Pain killers like lidocaine and xylocaine and novocaine almost don't work 
on me. Now I understand why the person wielding the needle never bats an 
eyelash when I tell them I'm going to need extra.﻿

comments.author: Nick Wright

comments.text:
I'm still not convinced that both parents have to carry the gene. I'm 
naturally bright copper red from my dad's Scottish/Irish/Native American 
side of the family, as my sister, nephew, uncle, grandma, and cousin all 
have red hair on that side. However, while my mom is Irish, Hungarian, and 
German, her side is all blonde and light brown. If she does carry the gene, 
it's gotta be extremely far back, because it hasn't shown up for several 
generations. On the other hand, the pain reception is extremely true. I 
have an extreme phobia of needles (which sucks being that I have 
pre-melanoma freckles removed from my skin about every 2-3 years), and 
people just don't understand that for me it's not "just a pinch." I also 
hate being tapped or hit lightly, because while it doesn't bother most 
people it's extremely irritating to me, even painful sometimes.﻿
comments.author: Natalie Johnston

comments.text:
+Natalie Johnston Agree, Natalie. It's not true that both parents need to 
carry the gene. In fact, both of my parents have dark hair. My mom - jet 
black, my dad - very dark brown. Both have olive skin. You can only imagine 
the jokes they got with their kid (me) being a carrot top. Except that I do 
look a lot like my dad, as well as my mom. The secret to my redhead 
heritage is my grandfather on my mom's side. He was a very fair skin 
redhead with freckles. My mom, even though has black hair, also has 
freckles. So there you go - redhead gene overpowered all the other. And 
yes, my son also has a very fair complexion and reddish blond hair, even 
though his father had dark hair, as everyone else did in his bloodline 
family.

a single copy of the gene himself.

comments.text:
My whole family is ginger, but I only get red hairs in a few places. I do 
have blue eyes, pale skin, and freckles. My body burns off all meds. 
Lidocane either doesn't work, or I need alot (thought I have a high pain 
threshold). When I was going in for surgery and my arms were shattered, so 
they couldn't strap me down tightly, I broke free. The Surgeon yelled "push 
more anesthesia" the anesthesiologist said "I've already given the max". So 
they pushed more, and after surgery a nurse had to sit with me and shake me 
awake every now and then for hours so I could breathe.

Later, I had a PICC line (IV from the arm to the heart) for two months. My 
doctor accused me of not taking my meds, I was on 9x a normal dose, but 
wasn't responding. So I had to take a unit in front of them, and got tested 
two hours later. The results showed levels equivalent to someone who hasn't 
had the medicine for at least a day.

I have a super liver.﻿

comments.text:
UPDATE INFORMATION.OK since I've had some replies saying this is not 
true,here's the update,the following information only applies to RED Headed 
boy's & Men in the United Kingdom.A colleague once told me & he did have 
red hair,he is a geneologist,although it wasn't the really bright red,more 
a browny red,anyway he once said Red hair is OK if you are a woman,but if 
you are a boy or man it's basically a life sentence of misery & hell.From 
his research in a scientific paper produced came the following,that was not 
allowed to be published.

If you are a Male red head you will never be able to attract a really HOT 
looking woman unless you are very wealthy,woman in the U.K. hate men with 
red hair this is a proven fact which is taught from Mother to Daughter 
never to get into a relationships with men who have red hair,it is seen as 
a humiliation & if ever the relationship produces children there will 
always be the acceptance & bullying aspect the child will suffer through 
life especially if the child is male.

So the facts.
1.If you are Female with red hair your life should OK.

2.If you are Male with Red hair your life may be full of unhappiness & 
misery & hell due to the unacceptance from society & attracting a mate for 
life may be impossible.

3.The Female of the species Mother to Daughter & so on is always informed & 
taught never to enter into relationships with Males with Red Hair due to 
the reproduction of children that could be born with red hair especially if 
(Male).

This information was taken from a scientific research paper that was not 
allowed to be published.

Society needs a major attitude shift in my opinion,Hair is Hair wether 
Red,Brown,Black or Blonde it makes no difference its only hair.

P.S.The information regarding Male's with RED hair is meant more for the 
United Kingdom especially England.﻿

no different from any other hate, but it gets overlooked because of 
hypocrisy-- i.e. double-standards based on popularity vs. logic.
comments.author: Simon Purist

comments.text:
The probable reason that it wasn't published was that it lacked SCIENTIFIC 
research, his statements needed to be verified and supported by a mountain 
of evidence. When you send off your research paper to be published in a 
journal it will be scrutinized by professors that are well versed in the 
area of study. 
So your 'friends' paper wasn't published because it lacked validity and 
support this was agreed upon by a number of his peers in the scientific 
community.
also publishing a paper stating that the reason for the problem or your 
lack of mating opportunities is because of women is narrow minded and leads 
many to think that the paper is insinuating that women should not have a 
choice over who they mate with or who they are attracted to. and papers 
like that don't offer any useful insight into how genes work and human 
behavior.
